definition: to dispose of/to spend (money)/to undertake a task

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc
variant of 出[chu1] (classifier for plays or chapters of classical novels)
hand/(formal) to hold/person engaged in certain types of work/person skilled in certain types of work/personal(ly)/convenient/classifier for skill/CL:雙|双[shuang1],隻|只[zhi1]
not presentable/shoddy and too embarrassing to show
not presentable/not fit to be seen in company
to get one's hands free (to do sth else)

sentences.english: Meng shu and liu to fisticuffs, as a result, liu pain beat.
sentences.chinese: 为此孟蜀和刘地大打出手，结果刘地被痛揍一顿。

sentences.english: He stretched and shook with me.
sentences.chinese: 他伸出手和我握了握手。

sentences.english: Two very drunk men were fighting over the only girl there.
sentences.chinese: 两个醉汉为了争夺那里唯一的女孩大打出手。

sentences.english: Mrs. Struthers extended a hail- fellow hand to Archer.
sentences.chinese: 斯特拉瑟斯太太向阿切尔友好地伸出手。

sentences.english: At that price everybody who wanted to buy yen for dollars would find someone who was willing to sell him yen for dollars.
sentences.chinese: 只有在这种兑换价位时，美元出手了才有人愿意接手。

sentences.english: Nothing says "novice" like a lunging, line-drive shot that comes from your chest.
sentences.chinese: 突破，急停然后从胸部出手投篮，说明你是一个新手。

sentences.english: Coach a hand, the children will go down.
sentences.chinese: 教练一出手，孩子便应声倒下。

sentences.english: Of course you may hope to sell long before then.
sentences.chinese: 当然你或许不会等那么久，提早出手抛售黄金。

sentences.english: The Angel then moticed something and reached out and touched the woman's cheek.
sentences.chinese: 这时天使注意到什么，伸出手触摸女人的面颊。

sentences.english: He held out his hand unflinchingly for the cane.
sentences.chinese: 他毫不畏缩地伸出手去挨藤条打。

sentences.english: Actually, this trade is likely to be totally irrelevant. But Wafer can shoot the rock, and Portland likes shooters.
sentences.chinese: 但是瓦佛能在三分线外出手，而开拓者喜欢射手。

sentences.english: Sooner or later the US Treasury and the Fed had to draw the line and the financial sector will eventually be healthier as a result.
sentences.chinese: 美联储和财政部迟早会出手，最终金融机构也会康复。
比赛最后时刻，邓肯三分出手。

sentences.english: He extended his hand cordially for handshaking.
sentences.chinese: 他热情地伸出手来和大家握手。

sentences.english: Tyrion stretched a hand out for his dragon.
sentences.chinese: 提利昂向他的龙伸出手。

sentences.english: They also enjoy better resale value if you need to part with them.
sentences.chinese: 如果要将它们出手，它们转售时的价值也更高。

definition: to start/to put one's hand to/to set about/the seat to the right of the main guest
to make a move (in martial arts or figuratively)
to strike back/to beat back/to counterattack
(of a performer) to come onto the stage to perform/(of an athlete) to enter the arena to compete/(fig.) to enter the scene (e.g. a new product)/(of an examinee etc) to leave the venue
to utilize/to put sth to use
to stop/to pull back
to hit (a target)
to go smoothly/to come off/to succeed
fault/mistake/to miss (a chance)
see 搶風|抢风[qiang1 feng1]
to fight over/to rush/to scramble/to grab/to rob/to snatch
somewhat/to some degree
to be present/to be on the scene
to sally/to attack
to observe and make sure/to check
in fact/in reality/actually/as a matter of fact/de facto/ipso facto
opponent/rival/competitor/(well-matched) adversary/match
